DOC.brief_summary: In Netherlands , 200.000 birth per year , maternity care provide midwife general practitioner unless medical reason necessitate specialist obstetric care . Women low risk pregnancy free decide give birth , attend midwife general practitioner , home hospital , discharge within 24 hour . In Netherlands hospital birth refer `` poliklinische bevallingen '' ( i.e . outpatient delivery ) indicate involve formal hospitalisation , `` verplaatste thuisbevalling '' ( i.e . relocate home birth ) indicate supervise caregiver home birth without involvement specialist obstetrician . In last two decade mark increase referral rate obstetrician childbirth occur , especially nulliparae , plan home birth plan hospital birth ( outpatient delivery ) . 90 % primigravidae start pregnancy care primary caregiver ( midwife general practitioner ) . During pregnancy 30 % refer secondary caregiver ( obstetrician specialist ) . The 60 % start labor guide primary caregiver . More 50 % woman refer obstetrician labor . Despite unique situation Dutch maternity care , differences home hospital birth ( outpatient delivery ) regard effectivity efficiency never investigate . It also unclear pregnant woman inform 50 % risk transport secondary caregiver/ hospital labor home . Neither know experience . This study aim investigate difference home hospital delivery care primary caregiver regard effectivity ( cost ) efficiency ( patient satisfaction ) care .
DOC.criteria: Primiparae No medical indication specialistic care The pregnant woman able give birth home hospital The woman partner fluent Dutch language
